#!/bin/bash
function updatepk() { if [ ! -z $1 ]; then if [ -e /var/run/yum.pid ];then exit 10 fi result=`yum -y update $1 2>&1` status=$? commandexist=`echo $result | grep -E "yum: command not found"` if [ "$commandexist" != "" ]; then exit 8 fi
commandexist=`echo $result | grep -E "yum: No such file or directory"` if [ "$commandexist" != "" ]; then exit 8 fi
islock=`echo $result | grep -E "lock /var/run/yum.pid"`
if [ "$islock" != "" ]; then exit 10 fi
islock=`echo $result | grep -E "/var/run/yum.pid: another copy is running"`
if [ "$islock" != "" ]; then exit 10 fi
isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "There was an error communicating with RHN"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi
isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "This system is not registered with RHN"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi
isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "No Repositories Available to Set Up"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "Error Class Code: 9 Error Class Info: Invalid System Credentials"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi isscriptletfailed=`echo $result | grep -E "error:" | grep -E "scriptlet failed, exit status 255"` if [ "$isscriptletfailed" != "" ]; then exit 6 fi if [ $status -ne 0 ];then exit 7 fi fi } updatepk pam_pkcs11
exit 0

Vulnerability.Title: pam_pkcs11 enhancement update
Vulnerability.Description: The pam_pkcs11 packages allow the X.509 certificate-based user authentication. The packages provide access to the certificate and its dedicated private key with an appropriate Public Key Cryptographic Standards #11 (PKCS#11) module. This update adds the following enhancement: Previously, when using LDAP to map a user certificate to a user ID, the pam_pkcs11 module requested a list of all certificates and IDs from the LDAP server and filtered this list, instead of using LDAP filtering. This approach caused performance problems on both the client and the server, and limited the ways LDAP could be used to map certificates. With this update, the querying algorithm for pam_pkcs11 has been improved and obtaining entire lists of certificates and IDs is no longer necessary. Logins using this module are now faster and require less resources, and pam_pkcs11 users now have more flexibility in using LDAP to map a certificate to a user ID. (BZ#1163922) Users of pam_pkcs11 are advised to upgrade to these updated packages, which add this enhancement. Note for remediation: Please disable the SELinux for RHEL 4/5 when repairing, or some rpm packages will fail to install.
